Since buying Belleair’s public golf course and turning it into the private Pelican Golf Club, The Doyle family has spent millions of dollars on a big new clubhouse and other enhancements..  [LUIS SANTANA | Times] [ LUIS SANTANA  |  Times ] By Susan Taylor Martin Times staff Published Susan Taylor Martin Bay Magazine Correspondent MORE FOR YOU British pub The Moon Under Water finally has a new home • Food Chassahowitzka River campground will likely stay in public hands • Environment Advertisement Dick’s Sporting Goods completes multibillion-dollar deal to acquire Foot Locker • Business Florida is threatening local transportation like never before, leaders say • Business Former Water Street CEO will now head up Tampa’s Gasworx • Real Estate Florida launches its tax break on guns and ammo Monday • The Buzz on Florida Politics Should more Florida businesses have at-work daycare and other parent perks? • Florida Property insurance companies are thriving now. Private To give feedback about this listing, Contact us Photo Credits: Bel Air Country Club About Bel-Air Country Club ALL PRIVATE GOLF > California > Los Angeles > Westside LA Bel-Air Country Club is an exclusive private golf club located in the affluent neighborhood of Bel-Air. The meticulously maintained course is surrounded by lush greenery, towering trees, and breathtaking views of the surrounding hills. The club's pristine facilities and impeccable service make for a truly luxurious experience for its members. The clubhouse features elegant interiors, top-notch dining options, and an array of amenities including tennis courts, a fitness center, and a swimming pool. With its serene atmosphere and unparalleled beauty, Bel-Air Country Club is truly a golfer's paradise. Address 10768 Bellagio Rd, Los Angeles, CA 90077 Website https://www.bel-aircc.golf Email dpodas@bel-aircc.com Phone Number 1 (310) 472-9563 Year Built 1926 Privacy Club is fully gated. Hours of Operation Monday: 12:00 PM - 6:00 PM Tuesday: 12:00 PM - 6:00 PM Wednesday: 12:00 PM - 6:00 PM Thursday: 12:00 PM - 6:00 PM Friday: 12:00 PM - 6:00 PM Saturday: 12:00 PM - 6:00 PM Sunday: 12:00 PM - 6:00 PM â Hours are not currently available. Please contact the club for details Highlights Golf Course: 18-hole championship course Tennis Courts: 7 well-lit courts with on-site pro Fitness Center: State-of-the-art gym with trainers Swimming Pool: Heated pool with Jacuzzi and lifeguards Dining: Fine dining in Main Dining Room, The Grill, The Lounge, and The Patio Events: Hosts holiday celebrations, wine tastings, live entertainment Family-Friendly: Summer camps, babysitting, social events advertisement Bel-Air Country Club Community Gated Community Staffed Gate Adjacent Communities Inquire About The Community Meet Your private club real estate expert, local to Los Angeles and passionate about golf. Inquire to learn more about Bel-Air Country Club, it's community, and available homes in Bel Air. Click here to connect with ... Memberships / Cost at Bel Air Country Club All prices are estimated based on public information Bel Air Country Club Membership Type Contact Bel Air Country Club for details Initiation Fee Not Available Monthly Dues Not Available Golf Course Details at Bel Air Country Club Course Architect(s) William P. Bell,George C. Thomas, Jr.,Jack Neville,Robert Trent Jones, Sr.,Tom Doak,Eric Iverson Holes: 18 Par: 70 Length (Yards): 6482 Slope: 133 Rating: 72.0 Fairway Grass Bermuda Grass Greens Grass Bermuda grass Tee Box Highlights Iconic course, varied challenges Landscape Urban, affluent neighborhoods Walking Allowed: Yes Club Rentals: Yes Caddie Rentals: No Driving Range: yes Chipping Area: No Practice Green: Yes If you are looking for a private club that offers the best in luxury, exclusivity, and amenities, look no further than Bel-Air Country Club. Located in the heart of Los Angeles, California, Bel-Air Country Club is the ultimate destination for members who want to enjoy a variety of activities and services in a stunning setting. Golf, Tennis, Fitness, and More Bel-Air Country Club is home to a championship 18-hole golf course that was designed by William P. Bell and renovated by Robert Trent Jones Jr. The course is a challenge for golfers of all skill levels, and offers breathtaking views of the city and the hills. Whether you want to play a casual round with friends, join a tournament, or take lessons from a pro, you will find everything you need at Bel-Air Country Club. The club also features seven lighted tennis courts where you can practice your serve, rally with a partner, or join a clinic. The club has a professional tennis staff that can help you improve your game and have fun. You can also enjoy the state-of-the-art fitness center that has a variety of equipment and programs to suit your needs. From cardio machines and weights to personal trainers and classes, you can stay fit and healthy at Bel-Air Country Club. If you prefer to relax and unwind, you can take a dip in the 25-yard, heated swimming pool that has a Jacuzzi and lifeguards. You can also pamper yourself at the spa, where you can choose from a range of treatments and services that will make you feel rejuvenated. Fine Dining and Social Events Bel-Air Country Club is not only a place for sports and fitness, but also a place for fine dining and social events. The club has four dining venues that offer different cuisines and atmospheres. You can savor exquisite dishes prepared by world-class chefs using the finest ingredients in the Main Dining Room, The Grill, The Lounge, or The Patio. You can also enjoy a drink at the bar, or order from the extensive wine list. The club also hosts various events throughout the year that cater to the interests and preferences of the members. You can celebrate holidays, attend wine tastings, watch live entertainment, and more. The club also has activities for members of all ages, including summer camps for kids and family-friendly events. Bel-Air Country Club is a place where you can meet new friends, network with professionals, and have a great time. Join Bel-Air Country Club Today Bel-Air Country Club is an exclusive private club that provides its members with a luxurious and unique experience. With top-notch amenities and services, Bel-Air Country Club is the perfect place for you to enjoy your favorite hobbies, indulge in fine dining, and socialize with like-minded people. If you want to become a member of Bel-Air Country Club, contact the club today and discover the benefits of joining this prestigious private club. Bel-Air Country Club is a member of As a member of , Bel-Air Country Club members enjoy a number of benefits that comes with the connection created by the  clubs involved. Bel Air Country Club — UK Golf Guy Static.COOKIE_BANNER_CAPABLE = true; Home Course Ratings How I rate golf courses Current Ratings Ranked Courses Map UK & IRE Scotland England Ireland EUROPE France Greece Portugal Switzerland Norway The Netherlands USA R.O.W Australia Mauritius New Zealand United Arab Emirates BLOG UK Golf Guy Travel Favourite Courses About Home Course Ratings How I rate golf courses Current Ratings Ranked Courses Map UK & IRE Scotland England Ireland EUROPE France Greece Portugal Switzerland Norway The Netherlands USA R.O.W Australia Mauritius New Zealand United Arab Emirates BLOG UK Golf Guy Travel Favourite Courses About BEL AIR COUNTRY CLUB - 17 POINTS I can’t think of any city in the world with truly world class golf courses as close to its centre as Los Angeles. The architect George Thomas created courses here in the golden years of architecture. Every year Riviera is one of the stars on the PGA tour, and is probably the finest regular stop played by professionals. We get fewer glimpses of the other Thomas masterpiece - LACC North - but the Walker Cup and the US Open gave us a look at the magnificence of this course in 2022 and 2023. The third Thomas creation is maybe his most inventive. Bel Air Country Club is a triumph of determination and imagination over logic. The course is somehow routed through four canyons where one coherent golf course really shouldn’t really be able to exist. If you are heading to Los Angeles on a golf pilgrimage I would recommend you pick up a copy of Geoff Shackelford’s biography of George Thomas, ‘The Captain’. In it he not only tells the story of this extraordinary architect with panache but also details how each of his courses came into being. He tells how the club founder, Alphonso Bell ‘made his millions when he struck oil while searching for water in his orange grove. Investing his money wisely, Bell purchased all of the ‘countryside’ between Sunset Boulevard and the Santa Monica Mountain’. He then sold off various parcels of this land, for great financial gain, which led to quite the challenge when planning the routing for Bel Air. Deep canyons and ownership issues meant it seemed impossible to plot eighteen holes until Thomas came up with the idea of building a bridge over a ravine (now the tenth hole) to open up what would become the back nine. You will find several tunnels, and even an elevator in use in the attempt to make a coherent course from such an unusual piece of land. It shouldn't work, but it does!! The routing at Bel Air is truly ingenuous! The famous swing bridge that sits above the 18th hole at Bel Air One of several tunnels which help piece the landscape together Thomas built a tremendously clever, and striking, golf course. However, as it is hemmed in by canyons and property, lengthening the course at Bel Air hasn’t been an option over the years. Instead various architects have attempted to make their own mark on their course, and to toughen it up. Water was added, bunkers put in, greens shrunk. Indeed one set of the most distinctive features, the Mae West mounds, short on the 12th hole, were removed as they were deemed unfair. In his Confidential Guide, Tom Doak gave the course a ‘Doak score’ of 7. But he bemoaned the changes over the years and declared it the course he would like to restore above all others. Well, following such a public plea he got his wish and the course I played on a December day had been restored to its former glory by Doak’s Renaissance Golf. So much for the history lesson - what of the golf course? I never played it pre-Doak but it is clear a lot of attention has been put into recreating the Thomas course. The green complexes and bunkering were just tremendous - a joy to look at and a joy to play. The course rewards those with imagination around the greens. Just fire at the pins and you may find yourself in real trouble; observe and embrace the angles and you will be rewarded. Despite the elaborate routing, picking its way through four canyons, the course isn’t particularly intimidating from the tee. There is plenty of width and the rough wasn’t too much to be worried about. However, the approaches into these sloping greens, with extravagant run-offs, require precision. The opening stretch does a good job of setting you up for what is come. The first is a sweeping, downhill par 5 which makes sure everyone will get away from the clubhouse in style - thank you Mr Thomas. The sweeping first hole at Bel Air The course then shows its teeth at the demanding uphill second before giving us a tantalising par 3 at the third. Over the years the bunkers short of the green on this hole had been taken out and a pond installed. Doak has replaced the water with a sea of sand and our host informed us the hole was playing harder as a result. The par 3 third at Bel Air now has bunkers restored in front of the green But the restoration wasn’t just about increasing green sizes and bringing back original bunkers. Trees were eradicated from the course which means that it has this fairly open feel, despite the topography. This image of the par four 4th hole coming towards the camera and then the short par three 5th shows this to good effect. You can see all of the trees that have come out on both side of the fourth fairway and the green opened up. The green then merges pretty much straight into the 5th tee. The 5th has been meticulously restored to the original design with the green moving forward and rotating, with bunkers the full width of the green front and back. Hitting the green on this one is only half the battle as the slope from back to front is quite something. The fourth and the fifth at Bel Air - pre and post restoration. The lovingly restored 5th green at Bel Air All of this work has delivered a course which is fun and accessible. Taking out trees and increasing the sizes and complexity of greens all make for an enjoyable experience. The run of holes back to the clubhouse continues to provide plenty of entertainment. The holes are rarely long but are packed with strategy and call for a good golfing brain to score well. After winding back to the clubhouse you then go through a corridor, and even up an elevator, to the 10th tee. This is a stout par 3 of over 200 yards which takes you over the ravine, moving to the west side side of the property. It’s a spectacular setting and oh how I wish I could go back and do something other than top it into the depths below... I won’t go through the back nine hole by hole, but there are a few worth a shout out. The eleventh is a great dogleg around to the left, with a narrow-angled green flanked by bunkers on both sides of approach. The well protected 11th green The Mae West mounds on the 12th are back in action and there are no bunkers at all on this hole now. Angles really are important to scoring well. The finish at Bel Air is strong. After the well protected downhill 16th you go through one last tunnel to get you back to the clubhouse. The 17th is a massive dogleg to the right where the challenge from the tee is all about how much you want to chew off. I played safe to the left leaving a long shot in; cut off the corner and a nice forward bounce will take you way down this long par 4. It really is a great hole. You have been conscious of what is to come at the 18th right from the off. The hole runs parallel to the 1st so you get a good view at the start, and again crossing over to the 10th. The par four climbs back up to to the clubhouse with the swing bridge sitting above. Darkness was descending fast as we approached which served only to make the hole seem even more demanding. Hazards abound - water runs down the right of the hole, there’s a centreline bunker short and pull one left and you will have problems on the bank. It’s one of the tougher holes on the course and you can expect a good audience on the patio above. The view down 18 from the swing-bridge overhead Much is made of the club atmosphere at Bel Air. We were told that Riviera is the corporate club, LACC is for the money guys but Bel Air is where the fun is at. It is hard to comment on that too much. The clubhouse was closed when we were there so we were in the (incredibly impressive) temporary erection. Tens of millions are being spent on a new clubhouse with a massive patio. It really will be one of the great viewing spots in the game. If you are lucky enough to get a round, try to make sure you get some anecdotes from your host. Fame and fortune proliferate here and part of the fun at Bel Air is the association with the great and the good of Hollywood. The stories are legion. Howard Hughes landed his plane on the 8th fairway to impress Katherine Hepburn, the caddie’s tell of Johnny Weissmuller filming scenes for one of his Tarzan movies in a hidden cave above the fourth hole. It goes on and on. George Thomas’s legacy to American golf, and to Los Angeles specifically, is tremendous. While the routing is amazing, that shouldn’t overshadow what is also a very good golf course. Tom Doak has opened our eyes once again to what a marvel this place is. TOUR TIPS Bel Air is certainly in the genre of ‘really hard to get on’ private American courses. But there are a few possibilities worth considering. Firstly, charity rounds do come up relatively regularly so it’s worth setting up a Google alert for those. Secondly, if you are a member of a club yourself, then have a look at Thousand Greens which may help. And thirdly, sometimes a nice letter does the trick...! CONTACT DETAILS Bel Air Country Club 10768 Bellagio Rd, Los Angeles, CA 90077, United States Web - https://www.bel-aircc.golf Phone - +1 310-472-9563 BACK TO USA → Back to Top

About Us - Belleair Development Group Skip to content Home Available Properties Completed Projects Map About Us Contact Menu Home Available Properties Completed Projects Map About Us Contact About Us Our Purpose We strive to deliver quality projects that positively impact the communities around us. —   Colossians 3:23   — Established in 1997, Belleair Development Group is a family business focused on developing assets for a long-term hold strategy. We are a privately-held, self-funded development firm operating throughout Florida. Our primary business focus is on commercial retail and multi-family development with projects ranging in size from single-tenant banks and gas stations to larger big-box and grocery-anchored centers. Since our inception, we have delivered over 400 commercial and residential projects, and we continue to look for opportunities today. Belleair has also partnered with some the country’s most prominent single-family, multi-family and hi-rise home builders to bring quality residential projects to the market.
